uni.name: Governance Foundation
uni.about: When reviewing any codebase, the first step is understanding the governance model, if it exists. This determines whether permissioned functions and elevated privileges are ultimately controlled by tokenholders.

criteria.name: On-chain Workflow Control
criteria.about: Does an on-chain workflow exist that gives holders ultimate voting power? (e.g., Timelocks or DAOs).
criteria.notes:
Users create a proposal on a forum, then on an off-chain snapshot and later, on-chain, after which, delay occurs before the execution.

Governance Flow: RFC → Snapshot Poll → GovernorBravoDelegator → Timelock

criteria.name: Access Control managed by Holders
criteria.about: Are all significant privileged roles (those impacting value/ownership) gated by the holder workflow and revocable?
criteria.notes:
All critical roles flow through governance-controlled contracts, ensuring UNI holders maintain ultimate control over the protocol.

V2Factory: feeToSetter role is held by Timelock contract. Only feeToSetter can call setFeeTo() to change where protocol fees are sent.

V3Factory: Factory owner is V3FeeAdapter, whose feeSetter is Timelock. Only Timelock can change V3 protocol fees via setProtocolFee() in UniswapV3Pool.

V4PoolManager: PoolManager owner is Timelock. Only owner can call setProtocolFeeController() to control who can set protocol fees.

UNI Token: Minter role is held by Timelock contract. Only minter can call mint function. Since Timelock is controlled by GovernorBravoDelegator, hence, all operations are controlled by UNI holders.

criteria.name: Governance Concentration
criteria.about: does any one group control a majority share of the voting supply?
criteria.notes: Aragon has not verified that 3rd parties do not hold more than 50% of voting power

uni.name: Metric 1: Token Control (On-chain)
uni.about: Token ownership and protocol ownership are separate questions and must be analysed independently. The core question here is straightforward: can a third party meaningfully interfere with ownership of the token?

criteria.name: Upgrade Sovereignty
criteria.about: Do holders control the upgrade logic via governance, or is the contract immutable?
criteria.notes: Token contract is immutable with no proxy patterns, no delegatecall, no EIP-1967/UUPS patterns.

criteria.name: Supply Sovereignty
criteria.about: Is the supply fixed/programmatic, or do holders control the minting process? (No third-party "Minter" roles).
criteria.notes: Mint can be called once per year which mints 2% of total supply. Note that mintCap is constant and can not be changed. Minter is set to Timelock governed by token holders.

criteria.name: Censorship Immunity
criteria.about: Are there no "Guardian" or "Admin" roles capable of freezing, blacklisting, or seizing tokens?
criteria.notes:
No blacklist, whitelist, or pause functions in UNI token contract. Transfers cannot be censored.

Standard ERC20 with no admin controls over transfers.

uni.name: Metric 2: Protocol Control (On-chain)
uni.about: Rather than analysing everything, we focus on what directly affects ownership and value. We look for two things: which contracts are in scope for tokenholder control and which privileged roles sit outside tokenholder control. This requires understanding the access-control patterns used in each contract, including proxies and upgrade mechanisms.

criteria.name: Upgrade Sovereignty
criteria.about: Do holders control the implementation logic of the specific "Engine" or product?
criteria.notes:
All Uniswap Pair contracts and Timelock are non-upgradeable, where as GovernorBravoDelegator is upgradeable.

UniswapV2Pair.sol: Uses Create2 deployment.

UniswapV3Pool.sol: Uses NoDelegateCall protection.

PoolManager.sol(v4): Uses Singleton design.

GovernorBravoDelegator.sol: Admin (who can upgrade) is set to TimeLock contract which again requires governance flow to go through.

criteria.name: Privileged Access controlled by holders
criteria.about: Are significant ownership restrictions or protocol parameters (risk/economic) gated specifically by holders?
criteria.notes: No pause/freeze functions in V2 Pair, V3 Pool, or V4 PoolManager core contracts. No admin backdoors to steal funds. No emergency withdrawal or sweep functions.

uni.name: Metric 3: Value Accrual & Control (On-chain)
uni.about: Value accrual matters alongside token and protocol control. Without it, ownership claims rely almost entirely on expectation rather than mechanism. Value can accrue indirectly through assets held by treasuries or contracts. Note that this is only accretive, strictly speaking, if tokenholders control those assets or the IP they fund.

criteria.name: Accrual Active & Owned
criteria.about: Are value flows currently active and governed by holders (non-discretionary)?
criteria.notes:
Protocol fees across all Uniswap versions (V2, V3, V4) flow to governance-controlled destinations (TokenJar).

Value accrual is via burn mechanism - anyone can burn 4,000 UNI to claim accumulated protocol fees from TokenJar via FirePit.

FeeAdapter collects protocol fees by calling collectProtocol and sends them to TokenJar. The 4,000 UNI threshold can be changed by governance via Timelock.

criteria.name: Treasury Ownership
criteria.about: Is the protocol treasury programmatically controlled by the token-governance workflow?
criteria.notes:
The treasury (~$1.4B) at the time of writing, is entirely controlled by token holders.

UNI tokens were initially minted to EOA 0x41653c7d61609D856f29355E404F310Ec4142Cfb, which transferred portions to TreasuryVester 0x4b4e140d1f131fdad6fb59c13af796fd194e4135(which has recipient: Timelock).

Vester's claim() (callable by anyone) followed a schedule to gradually vest UNI to Timelock without rapid dilution. Funds held in Timelock require UNI governance proposals to execute transfers, ensuring tokenholder control.

criteria.name: Accrual Mechanism Control
criteria.about: Can holders modify accrual parameters (e.g., changing fee splits or rates)?
criteria.notes:
Token holders control the fee switch and burn threshold (in FirePit) through governance proposals.

UNI holders control fee routing across all versions through Timelock-governed ownership.

V2: feeToSetter is set to Timelock on UniswapV2Factory. Only feeToSetter can call setFeeTo() to change the fee destination.

V3: Owner of UniswapV3Factory is V3FeeAdapter, whose owner is Timelock. The factory owner can call setOwner() to change fee adapter control.

V4: Owner of V4PoolManager is set to Timelock. Only owner can call setProtocolFeeController() on V4PoolManager to change the fee controller.

Changing the Fees:
V2 Pools: Protocol fees can only be enabled or disabled, not adjusted.
V3 Pools: Protocol fee percentage can be changed by the pool owner via setFee.
V4 Pools: Protocol fees can be modified by the PoolManager owner through setProtocolFee.

uni.name: Metric 4: IP & Distribution (Off-chain)
uni.about: Onchain ownership is only one half the story, in many cases. Distribution controls coordination. Even with immutable contracts, the ability to shift users to a fork or new deployment can break the link between existing tokenholders and future activity.

criteria.name: IP Ownership (Brand)
criteria.about: Is there evidence of DAO/holder ownership of trademarks, logos, and brand names?
criteria.notes: Trademarks (UNISWAP, UNI) are owned by Uniswap Labs, not the DAO. Use is granted via Trademark Guidelines.

criteria.name: IP Ownership (NPD)
criteria.about: Do holders have legal rights to new product development (patents, trade secrets, proprietary codebase)?
criteria.notes: New products (like V4) are developed by Labs. However, the UNIfication agreement (Wyoming DUNA) binds Labs to DAO-funded service mandates.

criteria.name: Distribution (Website)
criteria.about: Does the DAO/token entity own the primary domain (rather than an individual)?
criteria.notes: Uniswap Labs has agreed to align the official interface (uniswap.org) with DAO governance under the 2026 Service Agreement.

criteria.name: Distribution (Socials)
criteria.about: Does the DAO have administrative control over primary channels (X, Discord, Telegram)
criteria.notes: Primary communication channels (X, Discord) are managed by Uniswap Labs but serve as the voice of the ecosystem.
